messageBody:
So said Levi Cook on 2002-11-13

>I'm w/ Craig,
>
>Let the db earn its keep... The corollary is don't test things that
can't
>possibly break.
>
>On the other hand, you could be paranoid and say "how do I know my DDL
is
>correct?".
>
>If you're that paranoid, I would recommend using the ant sql task.
>Basically
>write a smoke test
>that preforms an insert with nulls & make sure the build fails.
>
>-- Levi

I did this on a project in IBM and it helped me. Let me describe the
scenario.

I built a small software component -- about 20 classes. This component
had three objects that required persistence. In that organization, the
database schema was centrally controlled by a "Database Group". They
did not necessarily have total control over the database schema, but
they executed all changes to the database schema. Not wanting to
inflict incremental development on a group that didn't have the
bandwidth to accommodate me, I built my component with no persistence,
got the data model "right", then prepared the database schema for
submission to the database group. My goal was to make them happy by not
making changes on them. They hate that.

Some of my tests involved checking the unique keys on the database
tables by trying to create persistent objects with various combinations
of values for unique keys and expecting "duplicate key" errors at the
right times. Some people might have seen those tests as testing the
database management system's implementation of unique keys, but I saw
it as testing whether the database group got my tables right.

As it turned out, they didn't. They messed up one of my unique key
constraint specifications because they were importing my
expertly-crafted DDL into ERWIN, then using ERWIN to spit DDL out
again. I felt that they were slaves to their tools, but I wasn't about
to tell them that. In the end, I was happy I wrote those tests.

Now, had I been in control of my own DDL, I might not have written
those tests; however, since I designed my component to abstract away
persistence, I wrote those tests to ensure that my in-memory
implementation of the persistent objects worked correctly. It needed to
reject the same kinds of duplicates that the database would.

Perhaps this gives you some more information to use to judge whether
you're testing the right thing.
